question: Which of the following is a non-reducing sugar?
tip: Among disaccharides, sucrose is the only non-reducing sugar because both anomeric carbons (C1 of glucose and C2 of fructose) are involved in the glycosidic bond — no free -CHO or hemiacetal group remains.

question: Glucose and fructose give the same osazone on treatment with excess phenyl hydrazine. This is because:
options: \text{C1 and C2 are involved in osazone formation — glucose and fructose have identical configurations at C3, C4 and C5}
\text{Both contain the same number of hydroxyl groups}
answer: \text{C1 and C2 are involved in osazone formation — glucose and fructose have identical configurations at C3, C4 and C5}
tip: Osazone destroys the structural difference at C1 and C2 — leaving C3–C5 intact. Since glucose and fructose share identical C3–C5 configurations, they give the same glucosazone.

Fructose does not reduce bromine water but does reduce Tollens and Fehling reagents. The correct explanation is:
options: \text{Bromine water oxidises only aldehydes (aldoses); fructose is a ketose. Tollens/Fehling work in alkaline conditions where fructose isomerises to glucose via enolisation}
\text{Fructose has a different ring structure that prevents all oxidation}
\text{Bromine water is a weaker oxidant than Tollens reagent}
\text{Fructose reduces Tollens because it has more hydroxyl groups}
answer: \text{Bromine water oxidises only aldehydes (aldoses); fructose is a ketose. Tollens/Fehling work in alkaline conditions where fructose isomerises to glucose via enolisation}
tip: Bromine water test is selective for aldoses — it distinguishes aldose from ketose. Tollens/Fehling use alkaline medium → ketose isomerises to aldose → reduces the reagent. This is why Br2 water but not Tollens/Fehling can differentiate glucose from fructose.

options: \text{Grams of iodine absorbed by 100 g of oil/fat}
\text{Milligrams of KOH required to neutralise 1 g of fat}
\text{Milligrams of KOH required to saponify 1 g of fat}

answer: \alpha\text{-helix or }\beta\text{-pleated sheet maintained by hydrogen bonds}

question: Amylose (20% of starch) and amylopectin (80%) differ in that:
options: \text{Amylose is unbranched (1,4-glycosidic bonds only); amylopectin is branched (1,4 and 1,6-glycosidic bonds)}
\text{Amylose is a polymer of fructose; amylopectin is a polymer of glucose}
answer: \text{Amylose is unbranched (1,4-glycosidic bonds only); amylopectin is branched (1,4 and 1,6-glycosidic bonds)}

question: All naturally occurring α-amino acids (except glycine) are L-amino acids and optically active. Glycine is optically inactive because:
options: \text{Glycine has two identical substituents (H) on the alpha carbon — no chiral centre}
\text{Glycine is the smallest amino acid and too light to rotate plane polarised light}
\text{Glycine exists only in zwitterion form which cancels optical activity}
answer: \text{Glycine has two identical substituents (H) on the alpha carbon — no chiral centre}

Which of the following correctly matches the hormone with its function?
options: \text{Adrenaline — increases pulse rate and blood pressure; releases glucose from glycogen}
\text{Thyroxin — controls normal functioning of male sex organs}
answer: \text{Adrenaline — increases pulse rate and blood pressure; releases glucose from glycogen}
tip: Common traps: Insulin decreases blood glucose (not increases). Glucagon increases blood glucose (opposite of insulin). Thyroxin stimulates metabolism — not sex organs (that's testosterone/estrogen).

question: Lactose is a reducing disaccharide made of glucose + galactose. Souring of milk is due to:

\text{Hydrolysis of lactose to glucose and galactose}
\text{Dehydration of lactose to form a polysaccharide}
answer: \text{Conversion of lactose to lactic acid by bacteria}

question: Among the 20 amino acids needed for protein synthesis, 10 are essential amino acids. They are called essential because:

\text{They are required in larger quantities than non-essential ones}
\text{They form the active sites of all enzymes}
\text{They cannot be broken down by the body}
answer: \text{Human body cannot synthesise them and they must be obtained from diet}

question: Denaturation of a protein destroys its tertiary/secondary structure but not its primary structure. Which of the following does NOT cause denaturation?
tip: Denaturation disrupts secondary and tertiary structure (H-bonds, disulphide bonds, ionic bonds) without breaking peptide bonds. The primary structure (amino acid sequence) remains intact — that's why denaturation is different from hydrolysis.

question: Sucrose is a non-reducing sugar and does not give mutarotation. However, on hydrolysis it gives an equimolar mixture of glucose (+52.5°) and fructose (−92°), and the mixture is laevorotatory. This mixture is called invert sugar. The inversion of sign of rotation occurs because:
options: \text{Fructose has a higher magnitude of negative rotation (−92°) than glucose's positive rotation (+52.5°), so the mixture becomes net laevorotatory}
\text{Hydrolysis converts the dextrorotatory sucrose to two laevorotatory sugars}
\text{Both glucose and fructose are laevorotatory in the free state}
\text{The glycosidic bond cleavage reverses the optical activity of both sugars}
answer: \text{Fructose has a higher magnitude of negative rotation (−92°) than glucose's positive rotation (+52.5°), so the mixture becomes net laevorotatory}
